story:
The Healing Blues Project

In The Healing Blues Project faculty and students from Greensboro College are teaming with area musicians to work with local storytellers who are clients of the Interactive Resource Center struggling with issues including homelessness and post-traumatic stress disorder to turn their stories into blues songs.

Storytellers express their challenges to participating songwriters. Songwriters then collaborate with the storyteller to write and perform a song that will be included on The Healing Blues CD, crediting both the collaborators with the creation of the song.

Project proceeds will benefit Greensboro's Interactive Resource Center as well as the storytellers who are clients of the IRC. The IRC is an innovative day resource center for people experiencing homelessness that provides many crucial services to the homeless community.

The "Healing Blues" CD release celebration concert will be held at 4 p.m. Sunday, Oct. 5, at Gail Brower Huggins Performance Center, Odell Building, Greensboro College. The concert will feature Lawyers, Guns, and Money; the Greensboro College Gospel Choir under the direction of GC alumnus Jamar Tyree; The Fairlanes; plus members of The Healing Blues team, including Kristy Jackson, Neil Clegg, Jon Epstein, Sam Frazier, and more. 

Listen to WFDD public radio interview with project initiators David Fox and Ted Efremoff at 37.36 mark of the David Ford broadcast. 

How you can help

We ask you to help The Healing Blues project raise money for the IRC and the people they serve. Your contribution will help support the IRC as they provide job skills classes, shelter placement, showers, laundry facilities, medical assistance, arts programming, transportation assistance, case management, mail services and other services that reconnect those experiencing homelessness with the community.

We are looking to raise $30,000 in total. $20,000 of that money will go directly to the IRC. A portion of that money will go to the IRC clients who are storytellers on The Healing Blues Project.

$10,000 of the money will go to The Healing Blues project for the recording of The Healing Blues CD at Earthtones Recording Studio, paying studio musicians and creating 1,000 CD’s for distribution. A portion of that money will be used for the production of the three concerts and one public lecture for The Healing Blues project. The final portion of the money will be used to create the CD cover and package art as well as produce rewards for the contributors.

To get the recording process rolling, we have raised $2,000 through Power to Give, now we would like to raise the remainder of the cost of the CD and concerts.

Your generous contribution will not only support a great Greensboro community organization in the IRC but also a unique work of art that commemorates our fellow community member’s stories of struggle. The healing process of talking about and memorializing one’s struggle in living music permeates this project as it has permeated The Blues since the beginning of the genre. Please join the dozens of generous musicians, artists, students, teachers and community members in supporting The Healing Blues project!!

We ask that anyone who does donate, to please share this page with your friends on Facebook to raise awareness. Thank you.
Link is: https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/the-healing-blues

Perks

Original artwork for the CD by Greensboro College art student Gabrielle Harvin

You will be rewarded for your support by the exciting perks that include a download of The Healing Blues CD, A copy of The Healing Blues CD autographed by The Healing Blues Band, Tickets to the Healing Blues CD release celebration concert at Greensboro College or a private concert by the Healing Blues Band at your residence.

Healing Blues Concerts and Events

A benefit concert, co-sponsored by ArtsGreensboro, featuring Dave Mcracken and Friends, including Sam Frazier and members of Donna the Buffalo, and The Healing Blues Band (Dave Fox, Roger Kohrs, Chuck Cotton, Benjy Johnson, and other Healing Blues songwriters and performers to be announced), 8 p.m. Thursday, Sept. 25, at the Blind Tiger, 1819 Spring Garden St. in Greensboro. Admission has yet to be determined and will be announced by ArtsGreensboro.

A Healing Blues Communion Service, 11:30 a.m.-noon Thursday, Oct. 2, in Hannah Brown Finch Memorial Chapel on the Greensboro College campus. Music by Healing Blues songwriters and musicians, along with college faculty members Dave Fox and Neill Clegg. Free and open to the public.

A Greensboro College Citizen-Scholar Series lecture and panel discussion, "The Art of Healing:  Social Practice Art and Communities of Need," featuring panelists Patrick Frank, author and singer-songwriter; Jessica Moore, founder and lead organizer at Open Art Society; George Scheer, executive director of Elsewhere Living Museum; Liz Seymour, Director Emeritus of the Interactive Resource Center; and GC associate professor Dave Fox, music director for Healing Blues, with discussion moderated by GC assistant professor Ted Efremoff, 4 p.m. Friday, Oct. 3, 109 Proctor Hall West on the Greensboro College campus. Free and open to the public.

The "Healing Blues" CD release celebration concert, 4 p.m. Sunday, Oct. 5, Gail Brower Huggins Performance Center, Odell Building, Greensboro College, featuring Lawyers, Guns, and Money; the Greensboro College Gospel Choir under the direction of GC alumnus Jamar Tyree; The Fairlanes; plus members of The Healing Blues team, including Kristy Jackson, Neil Clegg, Jon Epstein, Sam Frazier, and more. Admission: $15 at the door and includes a one-hour, meet-and-greet cocktail reception in Lea Center before the concert from 3 to 4 p.m.

Challenges

This is a project with many challenges as we are working to create a CD, put on three concerts and a lecture and raise funds simultaneously.  Despite that we are very confident that we will achieve our goals because we have assembled a great team of contributors. Our team includes experts in music and stage production, the best of local musicians, Arts Greensboro and the Piedmont Blues Preservation society, as well as many more collaborators. We have had overwhelmingly positive support from community members and music lovers alike and feel empowered by that. Thank you for your support!!

Blind Tiger, 1819 Spring Garden St. in Greensboro. Admission has yet to be
determined and will be announced by ArtsGreensboro.
A Healing Blues Communion
Service, 11:30 a.m.-noon Thursday, Oct. 2, in Hannah Brown Finch Memorial
Chapel on the Greensboro College campus. Music by Healing Blues songwriters and
musicians, along with college faculty members Dave Fox and Neill Clegg. Free
and open to the public.
A Greensboro College
Citizen-Scholar Series lecture and panel discussion, "The Art of
Healing:  Social Practice Art and Communities of Need," featuring
panelists Patrick Frank, author and singer-songwriter; Jessica Moore, founder
and lead organizer at Open Art Society; George Scheer, executive director of
Elsewhere Living Museum; Liz Seymour, Director Emeritus of the Interactive
Resource Center; and GC associate professor Dave Fox, music director for
Healing Blues, with discussion moderated by GC assistant professor Ted
Efremoff, 4 p.m. Friday, Oct. 3, 109 Proctor Hall West on the Greensboro
College campus. Free and open to the public.
The "Healing
Blues" CD release celebration concert, 4 p.m. Sunday, Oct. 5, Gail Brower
Huggins Performance Center, Odell Building, Greensboro College, featuring
Lawyers, Guns, and Money; the Greensboro College Gospel Choir under the
direction of GC alumnus Jamar Tyree; The Fairlanes; plus members of The Healing
Blues team, including Kristy Jackson, Neil Clegg, Jon Epstein, Sam Frazier, and
more. Admission: $15 at the door and includes a one-hour, meet-and-greet
cocktail reception in Lea Center before the concert from 3 to 4 p.m.ChallengesThis is a project with many challenges as we are working to create a CD, put on three concerts and a lecture and raise funds simultaneously.  Despite that we are very confident that we will achieve our goals because we have assembled a great team of contributors. Our team includes experts in music and stage production, the best of local musicians, Arts Greensboro and the Piedmont Blues Preservation society, as well as many more collaborators. We have had overwhelmingly positive support from community members and music lovers alike and feel empowered by that. Thank you for your support!!

story:
The746House Flag Day Fundraiser Yard Sale

 This year we're helping the Westside Apostolate with our Flag Day yard sale fundraiser on June 14, 2014. 

  • The Apostolate is a small, non-profit organization dedicated to helping everyone with their low-cost and free clothing needs. Completely run by hard working and dedicated volunteers, the Apostolate is family-owned and non-denominational. 
  • The yard sale, our Flag Day Fundraiser, will be held at 746 Garfield NW 49504, near Sullivan Field, from 8am-4pm. 


  • Come meet GRIFF (GR Griffins) and Louie the Laker (GVSU) from 3-4pm
  • Local Grand Rapids businesses have donated gift cards for you to purchase for the fundraiser! El Granjero Mexican Grill, Story Cafe, Gravel Bottom Brewing, Southland Auto Wash, Cafe Stella, Curtis Cleaners, Esquire Hair Styling, Amsoil, Inc.
  • All perks not sold online will be available at the fundraiser sale the day of the event.
  • Even if we don't hit our goal here, all the donations go directly to the Apostolate.

The Apostolate Impact

  • Westside Apostolate Vision Statement: To keep families and individuals united and strong as they progress to overcome challenges and see the seed of hope blossom into the new beginning of tomorrow.
  • Volunteers are always needed at the Apostolate to hang and price clothing, sort donations and run a cash register. It is a great place to donate, volunteer, learn and shop.
  • Free clothing program to Medicaid recipients once per week. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Spread the word about our campaign, our fundraiser sale and the Apostolate on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, LinkedIn and Vine.
  • Come on over to the yard sale on Flag Day and spend some money for the Apostolate!

Thanks for all you do and we hope to see you at the Flag Day sale from 8-4.

story:
Hi there and thanks for checking out our IndieGogo page for the new vinyl!

I'm nuts about vinyl.  When I was young I would ride my bike to Tower Records in the bay area with what little money I had and salivate over what was on offer.  I can remember agonizing over the fact that I only had enough money for one record, but wanted twenty!  This was before the age of the internet (ya, I'm kinda old) so the only way to hear a band I was interested in was to buy a record.

Thankfully now almost the entire history of recorded music is at our fingertips via the device you are looking at.  This has been a boon to independent musicians like ourselves because of the ease with which our potential fans can find us.  We are so grateful.

But there is still something so special about vinyl.  Yes, the sound quality is better, but there is something else.  Maybe it's the large artwork that you can actually hold in your hands.  Or maybe it's the fact that you can't easily skip ahead or fast forward.  Vinyl requires longer listening. 

Whatever it is, I'm clearly not alone in my feelings.  El Ten Eleven fans are constantly asking us for more vinyl, particularly fans in Europe.  So here we are, trying to deliver!

The problem is that vinyl is quite expensive to manufacture.  We've been able to pay for most of this run ourselves but are falling a little short.  That's where you come in.  If we can just get a bit more money this will be paid for!

We recorded a new song called Favrile and added it to our latest ep, "For emily."  On this song I only use fretless bass (though I'm sure people will insist there are keyboards on it!) and Tim only played electronic and acoustic drums.  We're really proud of how it turned out, but it will ONLY be available on this vinyl.  You can hear a bit of it in the video we posted above.

If you can help us out by buying a copy (or copies!) we'd be really grateful!  If you aren't interested in vinyl, we have a really cool, limited edition screen-printed poster you can grab, and here is what the artwork for the poster looks like:


Thank you for your support!

Kristian

ete

story:
Hi.

We're Bennett. Thanks for checking out our campaign. 

We're a band of best friends (Nick Rolls, Nicholas James Warren and Josiah Gentry), and we're beyond excited to share the next step of our story with you. 

We have been making music together as Bennett for just over two years. In that time we have been through some of the most challenging and inspiring moments of our lives thus far. As three hopeful young guys, we look forward to a bright future of making more music that inspires and encourages people. 

We decided at the beginning of 2014 that this was going to be a big year for us. We have since lined up some wildly exciting opportunities and we finally feel like we are ready to put these things into action. It's at this pivotal point in our careers that we are turning to our fans for an extra stretch of support. We feel that this has to be huge and exciting for our fans, just as it will be huge and exciting for us.

So poke around our campaign and check out all of the awesome perks we've lined up for you. Don't forget to grab a pre-order for the album.

Cheers, 

Bennett

What We Need & What You Get

We are seeking support to cover a portion of our album production costs with this campaign. This includes manufacturing, studio-time, producer fees, travel expenses (we're commuting from Grand Rapids, MI to Nashville several times), and a publicity budget. 

The unique thing about this campaign is that it is largely designed to create an exciting experience to get our album. It gives sweet deals to you, our dedicated fans, and in-turn helps us continue to create music that matters to you. 

We have been blessed to have a big chunk of money fronted by a private backer and close friend to the band. They will match any and all contributions, up to $15K. So fund early and DOUBLE your contribution. 

This is a big step for us as a band

For the majority of our short career we have been touring around the country in support of our last release "A Brand New Start" which we are still incredibly proud of. But it's time for us to make a new statement. We've grown and matured, and so has our sound. We're ready for you to hear the best material that we've ever written, and this is your chance to tell us your ready to listen. 

Other Ways You Can Help

More than half the battle is getting the word out to those that can contribute. As well as just helping us create a buzz about who we are and what we do!

Make sure to check out the Indiegogo share tools to help you post onto social media!

You can connect on social media with us at:

www.facebook.com/bennettband

www.bennettband.com

www.soundcloud.com/bennettband

Instagram and twitter: @bennettband

Thanks for all your love and support! We're excited to take this next step alongside you.

story:
ABOUT

WHAT:  MUSIC & LIFESTYLE FESTIVAL

WHERE:  ISLAND PARK, WILLIAMSVILLE - BUFFALO, NY

WHEN: JUNE 28TH, 2014

TARGET AUDIENCE:  15 - 25 YEAR OLDS LOCAL YOUTH

EXPECTED ATTENDANCE:  1,200 PEOPLE THROUGHOUT THE DAY


HELLO!

Meet the Intune team. You can call us Intuners. We are a group of friends who came together to make something that matters. 

Left to right:

Juliana Pastoriza - Marketing | Design | Web Developer

Sarah Gutierrez - Food Vendor | Farmer Relations 

Pierce Flaherty - Artist Relations | Stage Logistics

Amanda Gutierrez - Business Relations | Project Management

Max Silver - Venue Logistics | Vendor Management

We operate virtually but each have personal ties to the Buffalo community. 


Our Vision

Start a positive chain reaction in our community, by inspiring individuals to become intune with themselves and others around them.

Our Mission

Create an inspiring environment with new music, possibilities and ideas regarding a wholesome lifestyle to encourage young adults to go after what makes them truly happy and aspire to live a fulfilling life.

We want to show through action and example that there are endless outlets to express themselves and grow in any direction.


THE FESTIVAL

Music

The festival will have one main music stage where music will be played consistently throughout the day. The line-up will be a combination of live bands and DJs, with the main act closing the night. 

There will be musical acts from different parts of the world with an emphasis on musicians based out of (or originally from) Buffalo. We aim to support local talent, introduce new music, and present artists that the crowd can relate to.

Workshops

This is where the magic happens! Aside from the music stage, there will be tents/kiosks where inspirational guests will be hosting workshops that showcase their passion. Whether it be yoga, culinary, film, photography, music production, painting or technology, these all represent the individual’s conscious choice of lifestyle. 

There will also be an Intuner Tent where select guests will be given a time slot to tell their story and talk about who they are and what they do in an open format. All of  these talks will be filmed for post-event material.


OUR INDIEGOGOAL

The festival is in TWO MONTHS. To make it happen in grand style we are asking for $10,000 for stage and equipment fees.

The more money we can raise with your contribution, the more professional facilities we'll be able to provide the artists to present and perform their work, delivering a greater experience to all of the festival's attendees. 

What we've been up to:

  • We have registered as an LLC (Limited Liability Company)
  • We've secured the event's location with a successful crowd-funded project
  • We are reaching out to possible sponsors and vendors
  • We have our website up and running www.intunefestival.com
  • We are building our social media following 
  • We have defined the music and workshops line-up
  • We have a team of 15 volunteers and a street team working with us
  • We are producing the festival's merchandise, decor and promo material 

Check out the awesome perks we have for our contributors ;)


ARE YOU IN(TUNE)?

You can help us by:

  • Contributing financially 
  • Sharing the link to this IndieGogo project
  • Promoting our website www.intunefestival.com
  • Liking our Facebook page 
  • Becoming a volunteer 

Stay intune!

story:
Art Should Not Be Free!

As writers, musicians and artists, we put our blood, sweat and tears into our work. Yet we often give away the result just to get credit. We post our artwork on blogs, upload our music to online communities and give away our poems to nonpaying publications. We also perform or display our work at public events with no financial gain.

Unfortunately, the economic strain drives many talented people away from creative work—especially in places like our rural community. Here, creativity is not only undervalued, it is discouraged. Self-expression has been reduced to brand names and sports logos. Our grandparents’ farm land is now a fast-food haven. In many ways, we are homogenized America, with our minimum-wage jobs and chain stores offering the same made-in-China landfill fodder. Our value is not in what we ourselves produce or create, but in what we buy—and how much. We are no longer citizens, but consumers.

Our Mission

We are working to fight the forces of creative oppression in our community. That’s why we started the Homegrown Art, Music & Spoken Word Show, an open-mic and arts exhibition series held bimonthly in Bullitt County, Kentucky. Our mission is to nurture local writers, musicians and fine artists by providing a platform to showcase their talents. And we accomplished part of that mission May 17 at our pilot show at Cedar Grove Coffee House.

If you were among the folks who packed the coffee shop that evening, then you witnessed something special—a magical blend of both budding poets and musicians, as well as more accomplished artists and artisans. We had a terrific time, and the energy we created lifted our spirits and our hopes to transform the culture of our community. We believe that art should not be free! Artists and artisans should be rewarded for their efforts and fostered to their full potential.

Make a Difference

We believe we can overcome creative oppression by rewarding the efforts of local artists and artisans and fostering them to their full potential. Funding for this campaign will go toward:

  • Honorarium for featured performer
  • Honorarium for featured artist
  • Honorarium to randomly selected open-mic performer
  • Honoraria for lead musicians and emcee
  • Sound equipment rental and operation
  • Publicity and promotion materials, including flyers and programs

Those who donate $20 or more to our campaign will have their names listed in the Homegrown show's program.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t make a financial contribution, that doesn’t mean you can’t help our campaign. You can help by spreading the word. Use the Indiegogo share tools to ensure our project gets full visibility and support.

story:
Students of all ages desire to engage in music but have little opportunity to explore its wonders in a small setting, let alone for some, any music program at all. If you are lucky enough to play music, you are inspiring to yourself and to the listener of your music.

We know how to make it work together, with our repertoire challenging the advanced students along side music that is challenging and enjoyable for intermediate levels. 

Our faculty passionately believes that students need not be on a path to being a professional musician, nor do students have to wait a long time before they can engage in music with others, be it classical, folk or a mix. Improvisation as well teaches students to be free with their newly-found ability and spirit. We will teach students the techniques that will spur them on to use improvisation in their music-making. Skills learned at this camp will go beyond "just" the skills, enhancing all they do in music and frankly beyond the music itself.

With degrees in performance, education and musicology combined, we will select music for the students - at their own level or above - music of Ireland, Israel, Africa, South America, Poland, Ukraine and Asia. The colors of the world in music, four days of study, playing and then a final performance. Pure joy while learning so much.
But, not everyone can afford to come.

PLUS, we need a few instruments. Here is where you come in!

We are raising funds for 8 full scholarships, 8 partial, plus a few world instruments. We would like to have our studio filled with students but, even in Fairfield County, this is a strectch for many. We are offering CDs and musical instruments as our gifts to you for your generous support. We promise you will be delighted with our choice of CDs to you, whichever it may be! A private coaching on your instrument is also possible, either via Skype or in person! The grand perk is a concert in your CT home! You can be that lucky "winner"!

Music is how we will all live together harmoniously. Trite? Not very unique? Perhaps, but nothing is frankly more "harmonious" than making music together, all ages, all cultures. Nothing. It is truly a secret that needs telling, over and over.

Please contribute what you can and you will be rewarded many times over!

Very sincerely, our faculty:

Adrianne Greenbaum, flutist, pianist, BM Oberlin, MM Yale; Professor at Mount Holyoke College

Ada Pasternak, singer-songwriter-violinist, BM Berklee College Presidential Scholar, NYC freelance

Rayhan Pasternak, Musicology, BM Bishkek (Kyrgyzstan), private violin studio, choir director

Rebecca Povodator, flutist, BM and MA, USC, teacher Brooklyn Public Schools, freelance orchestral flutist

Ada Pasternak, singer-songwriter-violinist, BM Berklee College Presidential Scholar, NYC freelanceRayhan Pasternak, Musicology, BM Bishkek (Kyrgyzstan), private violin studio, choir directorRebecca Povodator, flutist, BM and MA, USC, teacher Brooklyn Public Schools, freelance orchestral flutist

story:
The story of the Dickel Brothers reaches back as far as 1993. Matt & Joel Dickel relocated from SF to Portland, Oregon in the mid-90's kicking out the Dickel original "When I Die" telling the tale of hard times and a broken heart. Shortly after Joel Dickel moved to Washington, Clancy Dickel found his was into what was to become the core start of the Dickel Brothers Old-Time String Band sound. Clancy and Matt Dickel played up and down Portland, OR, with a weekly show at the original Delta Cafe. Within a couple years the The Dickel Brothers expanded in the family String Band as Michael, Marcus and Brian joined the fold. 1999 was a huge year for The Dickels. They recorded two full-length albums at the famous Jackpot Studios in Portland, both of which were released on eMpTy Records US, the iconic Seattle-based punk rock label. Throughout the heyday of the original 5 Dickel Brothers they had the pleasure of sharing the stage with Danny Barnes & The Bad Livers, Andrew Bird, Big Sandy & his Fly Rite Boys, Fireballs of Freedom, Hunger Mountain Boys, Tight Bros From Way Back When, and Everclear, to name a few. As brothers often do, Clancy and Michael sought out to far off lands, Brian sailed the seas, and thus the original 5 Dickel Brothers were no more. Luckily with modern technology the remaining Dickels found 2 more brothers in Portland: Jason and Nate Dickel. For a time the Dickel Brothers 4 roamed and rambled through the Great NorthWest sharing their renditions of Tin Pan Alleys and County Blues. 

   It's been over 10 years since the original 5 Dickel Brothers have played together, and this January 2014 the boys will be dusting off the old instruments to record at least 1 new original Dickel song, and with enough good rye whiskey, they hope to have a few new recording under their belts. As one of the perks of your generous contribution to the Dickel travel fund you get a digital download from this recording session of which will only be available for funding this project!

The Dickels will be playing a few shows in Portland, OR in the middle of January 2014: The Portland Old Time Music Gathering (1/17) & Red Flag (1/19) and a secret show we'll announce day-of. During our time together in Portland we will be recording a number of songs and tunes, some public domain and some originals. 

In being part of this funding you have to chance to pick up some rare and out-of-print Dickel gems, grab yourself a brand new Dickel original song, or have us play your favorite Dickel songs while standing on your office desk. Your contribution will go towards bringing Clancy Dickel and Michael Dickel back to Portland for this reunion and will help fund the new recording session. Any amount is greatly appreciated and we are happy to provide you with tons of great and rare prizes. 


A Million Thanks!

The Dickel Brothers

story:
Short Summary

We started this band less than a year ago with the hope of creating something great enough to share. After teaming up with some amazing people, we've finally gotten the chance to do that; and here we are. 

This Indiegogo is the last vital piece to our dream. With help from people as passionate about this as we are, we can put the finishing touches on what we've been working so hard on and share it with the masses. Having put everything we own (or owned) on the line for this, we're now reaching out for that last bit of help to make things happen.

With your contribution, no matter how big or small; we'll be able to finalize this full length record that we've put our entire lives into. 

What We Need & What You Get

Making an amazing sounding record is both time consuming and exponentially more expensive than you'd think. To put things into perspective, here's what it costs:

Recording & Production - $9,000

Mastering - $1500

CD Replication - $2000

Merchandise - $2000

So, clearly this is a lot more than we're asking for from you guys. We've saved money from our jobs, selling personal items, and living off of bulk ramen noodles just to make this work. The last $5000 will cover our finishing fees and the first run of merch that we can send out to our fans!

If you choose to back us, your donation will score you something awesome.

The Impact

For us, this is the biggest milestone in our lives. We've been striving to make great music; and now that we have, we just need that last little push to help share it with everyone. With your donations, you'll help make the dreams of four extremely motivated people come to fruition - and we won't let you down. 

We've been lucky enough to have some of the greatest people we know involved in this project. Starting with pre-production by Cody Payne (The Dangerous Summer/Hopeless Records), and now producer Paul Leavitt (All Time Low/Senses Fail/etc.), we've got the expertise and experience to fine tune everything we've already done ourselves. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't afford to contribute, you can still help! As a new band, exposure is really the first battle towards getting out there. If you can tell a few friends and they tell a few friends, we'll have that many more people aware of what we're doing. 

If you're into social media, share our Facebook/Instagram/Twitter pages to people that might like us. Any and all help is greatly appreciated!

story:
Did you see those pianos on the streets of Portland this summer? 

Thanks to everyone who came out to play or listen. If you want to see more amazing photos from this summer or read some of the lovely stories and comments we received please visit our Facebook....Indiegogo receives so much support from word of mouth so please share our story with others or submit your own. 

Facebook

That was Piano! Push Play!, a music outreach project, with one mission, to give everyone more access to this beautiful instrument.  We want it to be easier for everyone to play, listen and enjoy the piano. We believe performing for others in a casual setting is a key community practice for any musician. Through this project we saw the piano bringing together people from all walks of life, sparking conversations and communion amongst strangers, fostering those that aim to make a life in music and helping to bring a bit of joy, magic and MUSIC to everyone's day. 

 Throughout this summer we had 5 pianos outside on the streets of Portland, free for the public to play.  And PLAY! they did. There was barely ever a period of more than 5 minutes when one of our pianos wasn't being played. 

Now that the rainy season is upon us we want to find permanant homes for these 5 pianos. We want to donate to places in this city that will serve children, at risk-youth and spaces where the entire community can have year-round access to a piano to play, practice or write music on and share their music with others. Places like King School in N Portland, New Avenues for Youth and ADX, a community space and workshop. 

To accomplish this goal and bring this project full circle your help! 

We need to raise the funds to re-tune, service and move these pianos so that we can donate them to a permanent home. We also want to provide each new location with their first follow-up tuning and maintenance. 

Throughout this summer we organized lots of free concerts where young, locally-based pianists performed for the pubic in these exciting outdoor spaces. We discovered so many talented and emerging pianists and composers that live in this city and wish it was easier to play for people and with other musicians and singers.  We want to create more access to this instrument for everyone so players can share their gift with the community and inspire others to get involved in music. 

As a big part of our reward system we want to tap into all this local talent of incredible pianists and produce an album of their favorite piano pieces; from jazz to classical to original compositions. For many this will be their first opportunity to be professionally recorded and they couldn't be more excited!  We will produce a beautifully hand illustrated booklet with our physical C.D. profiling each pianist, why they picked each piece, their connection with the music/piano and an experience they had through this project. 

 smaller donations are super important and cover a whole host of things.

  • painting supplies and decorations for each piano
  • cleaning wipes for heavily used piano keys 
  •  media materials and printing
  •  site maintenance

        to learn more about how and where Piano! Push Play! started....video by Ifanyi Bell


 or check out these lovely articles and interviews about the project. 

Oregon Arts Watch                 Oregon Music News                       The Oregonian   

Art Museum Teaching          Oregon Public Broadcasting                AwesomePortland   

I really can't say THANK YOU!!! enough to everyone who helped this project be such a success this summer. From piano movers, to piano players, to total strangers who gave me such generous hugs and played their hearts out.  Let's complete the circle and give all these pianos another generation of use, LOVE, and beautiful music making. MUSIC FOR EVERYBODY. 

Risks and challenges

Recording and producing records can be a long process with unforeseen delays. I will do my absolute darnedest to get our C.D and other rewards to you by this Christmas.....they are the perfect gift for that musician in your life after all!

There are risks and challenges in any big undertaking but I couldn't have had better sponsors and support than the following organizations

------http://www.snowmanfoundation.org 
------http://www.portlandpianocompany.com 
------http://www.wcpianomoving.com

story:
Hello! My name is Matthew Linaman and I am a cellist. I recently graduated from the San Francisco Conservatory of Music and I am committed to bridging diversity and connecting humanity through inspired learning and music making. 

As I am on the rise on my international career, I am in need of a more dynamic instrument. I need a cello that has an endless palate of sounds and colors to connect with a global population with endless diversity. I was not expecting to have found “the one” so soon out of school, but after playing on this cello for just a few days, I discovered it has the unique power to connect to anybody, and to move every body out of their seats and into inspiration. 

I love this cello. It not only inspires me to practice, it inspires me to play better! It forces me to stretch everyday to it's great potential- to bring my best self to practice and performing, and to bring the best music I can to audiences. This cello will give me a competitive edge in competitions, auditions and will take me throughout my entire career .

I am doing everything in my power to fund this cello. I am only three months out of school and I have a full concert schedule in the fall and many appearances in the spring including being the Featured Soloist with the Oakland East Bay Symphony and an international tour with my string quartet, the CelloStreet Quartet. I teach a vibrant studio of students and I coach at several local schools. I get inspired when I can help others be inspired. That is why I love performing and teaching. I want to see inspired faces and shining eyes after my recitals and after my lessons. And it may not be because of how beautifully I did or didn’t play, it is because we realize the power of music- it allows us to transcend our differences and unite into an inspired collective where amazing things can happen.

So you must be wondering- what is this cello?! So I will tell you! This cello comes from a family of 19th Century French luthiers named the Chanot Family. It has superb craftsmanship and it in exquisite condition. However it is missing the maker’s label, a crucial part in the determination of the price. After having played 20 different cellos to confirm that the Chanot cello is the one, and after multiple professional feedback,  it is clear that the Chanot is a rare gem, that with a label, could go for 2-3 times as much. The lack of the label does not affect the sound of course and it does not effect the power it has to move people.

I am using this indiegogo campaign as a platform to fund this cello. I am maintaining my private studio, coaching at local schools, and booking more and more concerts. The world needs to hear this cello.

If you can’t contribute, please send this message to your friends, classmates, co-workers and relatives. Even if they can’t contribute,  by getting my message out you are helping my mission of making more classical music global.

I have set this campaign up so that I will receive all funds donated- and they will go straight to funding the cello. If there are additional funds, I will take a poll and decide to donate a portion to charity or local music school program.

story:
We are A Vocal Arts Ensemble of Houston. (aka: All Saints Vocal Arts Ensemble) Will we perform a Concert featuring Hispanic Composers on Sept. 14, 2014 @ 5 PM.  We do not charge admission for this concert.  It is free to the public so that we can enrich their lives with beautiful and culturally diverse music.  We are looking for support in order to bring this concert to this area of Houston. 

The concert will be at All Saints Catholic Church located at

215 East Tenth Street
Houston, Texas 77008-7025

It is with great pleasure that we announce the opening concert of the Sixth Season of the All Saints Cultural Arts Series on Sunday afternoon September the 14th 2014, at 5:00 pm. Performing that day will be the "All Saints Vocal Arts Ensemble" under the direction of Dr. Rick Lopez. Included in the concert will be the rousing "Missa Criolla" by Ariel Ramirez and the "Romancero Gitano" by Mario Caselnuevo-Tedesco. Guest soloists will be Tenor Angelo Ferrari and Bass Eduardo Lopez de Casas with Guitarist, Marc Garvin. Save the date for this Gala event.

We thank you for your support.

story:
For a more videos describing our work and our partner communities, please visit our gallery.

Music? For Development? Why?

All over the world there are communities with great ideas about ways to improve their quality of life, but many of them face financial barriers to putting these ideas into action.

These vibrant communities often perform amazing, unique music as part of everyday life.

Community Voice International is a nonprofit startup that sees music as a local resource which can be transformed into an asset to fund local development. By recording local music, selling the recordings online, and returning the proceeds back to the community of origin, we seek to generate seed funding to catalyze local development efforts. Because the cost of living is lower in our partner communities, a recording doesn't have to sell a million copies to make a difference—in fact, some projects can be funded by less than 100 downloads.

I'm David Bleckley, the founder of Community Voice International. I served in the Peace Corps in a small village in Senegal, West Africa. During my service, I took great joy in the music that permeated every facet of daily life, but I was also troubled by how difficult it was for the community to save up even $250 to fund projects that would dramatically improve community members' quality of life. Over the past several years, I developed the idea to transform local music into funds for local development efforts—an idea that became Community Voice International.

Over the past year, a small group of us created Community Voice and have been piloting this idea with Joshua, a Peace Corps Volunteer in Senegal. We have recorded music in two communities and will be releasing those recordings soon. Throughout the process we have identified ways to make the project better. Now, the time has come to scale up our project and expand our scope.

Music for Development is phase two of our pilot project. In April 2013, I will travel to Senegal to record music in at least seven more partner communities (we may be able to record several more, depending on funding and partnership interest). The project will be a collaboration with Joshua and other Peace Corps Volunteers as well as staff and volunteers from Tostan, a fantastic organization which trains and mobilizes communities to identify and plan local development efforts. These collaborators help Community Voice create relationships with communities which have plans for community development projects, barriers to complete these efforts, and an interest in working with Community Voice to transform local music into a development funding source.

Your support for this campaign will allow Community Voice International to become a reality and more importantly, will create a new stream of income to fund local development in our partner communities. 

Our Goal and Incentives

We hope that you agree that the idea of transforming music into funds for development work is worth pursuing. So, how much will it cost to move this project forward?

Our estimate is $18,525, which breaks down like this:

  • $6,450 to cover the cost of travel around Senegal, including food, fuel, and expenses for our partners and me;

  • $4,300 to be sent to partner communities as royalties for the incentives sent to our backers;

  • $4,075 to cover incentives and fees associated with the Indiegogo campaign;

  • $2,150 to buy recording equipment and supplies to record music and find out which equipment works best in the field;

  • and of course, $1,550 for roundtrip airfare from the US to Dakar, Senegal.

Community Voice uses digital distribution of partner communities' recordings in order to minimize infrastructure while maximizing both audience reach and funding for communities' development work. However, here on Indiegogo, in addition to digital downloads, we're offering some unique perks including limited edition CDs, photographs and stories from the field, and other chances to get connected with our work.

Plus, every track that we include in our incentive packages, whether download or physical recording, will automatically generate $1 for the community that produced the song (for example, if you support us at the $10 level and receive three downloads, $3 goes directly to the communities from which you download your songs).

Expand your impact in the final days: For the remainder of the campaign, for every new contribution made, we will give one additional download on top of your existing incentive (you must select an incentive to be eligible for this). You will not only get an additional song, but you will be sending $1 more to a partner community. That means your new $10 contribution will now generate $4 for the communities which performed the music you choose.

 

Announcing new incentives: we just added our "Drummer" and "Globe-trotter" levels of giving. Want to feel a greater physical connection with the cultures in Senegal? These incentives may be for you.

Bonus music from Adam Klein: From now until the end of the campaign for any new contribution of $100 or more, singer/songwriter, Returned Peace Corps Volunteer, and Community Voice Board Member Adam Klein is offering up two of his most recently relased CDs:

  • Malian music album Dugu Wolo, recorded in Bamako, Mali and featuring traditional West African instrumentation by some of Mali's master musicians
  • The new Americana/folk album Sky Blue DeVille

Adam is offering these in addition to the other incentives you will also receive at this level. Thank you for your generosity, Adam!

The Impact

The main goal of this project will be recording music from partner communities to sell online in order to fund local development work. Stay tuned for updates to find out the communities in which we'll be working and what projects they have planned.

Beyond realizing the mission of transforming music into funds for development, this campaign will also support Community Voice's work, allowing us to:

  • Streamline our recording process;

  • Experiment with different kinds of equipment to determine what works the best in the field;

  • And most importantly, to talk with members of our partner communities to find out how our work can better facilitate their development efforts.

Community Voice is pushing forward as an organization, trying to become more sustainable and effective at what we do. Your support will help us to prove that the concept of recording local music to fund local development really works. That proof of concept will allow us to help thousands of people in the years to come.

Other Ways You Can Help

Thank you all for supporting Community Voice International and our partner communities. We know that not everyone who supports our work will be able to contribute to this campaign; there are lots of other ways to help:

  • Tell your friends, family, neighbors, coworkers, pets, and complete strangers about our project and encourage them to check out our campaign on Indiegogo. The share tools above make it simple to share via social media or email.

  • Are you a whiz at web development? ...a PR guru? ...a master recording engineer? ...an ethnomusicology grad student? ...a philanthropic person with a few extra minutes? Volunteer for Community Voice! Contact me and let me know you're interested.
  • You're creative and have an amzing idea about how you contribute to our work. Please contact me and share your idea!

  • Like us on Facebook, follow us on Twitter, and visit our website to stay informed about new music releases and other Community Voice updates.

Thank you all for your support!
story_txt:
For a more videos describing our work and our partner communities, please visit our gallery.
Music? For Development? Why?
All over the world there are communities with great ideas about ways to improve their quality of life, but many of them face financial barriers to putting these ideas into action. 
These vibrant communities often perform amazing, unique music as part of everyday life.
Community Voice International is a nonprofit startup that sees music as a local resource which can be transformed into an asset to fund local development. By recording local music, selling the recordings online, and returning the proceeds back to the community of origin, we seek to generate seed funding to catalyze local development efforts. Because the cost of living is lower in our partner communities, a recording doesn't have to sell a million copies to make a difference—in fact, some projects can be funded by less than 100 downloads.
I'm David Bleckley, the founder of Community Voice International. I served in the Peace Corps in a small village in Senegal, West Africa. During my service, I took great joy in the music that permeated every facet of daily life, but I was also troubled by how difficult it was for the community to save up even $250 to fund projects that would dramatically improve community members' quality of life. Over the past several years, I developed the idea to transform local music into funds for local development efforts—an idea that became Community Voice International.
Over the past year, a small group of us created Community Voice and have been piloting this idea with Joshua, a Peace Corps Volunteer in Senegal. We have recorded music in two communities and will be releasing those recordings soon. Throughout the process we have identified ways to make the project better. Now, the time has come to scale up our project and expand our scope.
Music for Development is phase two of our pilot project. In April 2013, I will travel to Senegal to record music in at least seven more partner communities (we may be able to record several more, depending on funding and partnership interest). The project will be a collaboration with Joshua and other Peace Corps Volunteers as well as staff and volunteers from Tostan, a fantastic organization which trains and mobilizes communities to identify and plan local development efforts. These collaborators help Community Voice create relationships with communities which have plans for community development projects, barriers to complete these efforts, and an interest in working with Community Voice to transform local music into a development funding source. 
Your support for this campaign will allow Community Voice International to become a reality and more importantly, will create a new stream of income to fund local development in our partner communities. 

Our Goal and Incentives
We hope that you agree that the idea of transforming music into funds for development work is worth pursuing. So, how much will it cost to move this project forward?
Our estimate is $18,525, which breaks down like this:


$6,450 to cover the cost of travel around Senegal, including food, fuel, and expenses for our partners and me;


$4,300 to be sent to partner communities as royalties for the incentives sent to our backers;


$4,075 to cover incentives and fees associated with the Indiegogo campaign;


$2,150 to buy recording equipment and supplies to record music and find out which equipment works best in the field;


and of course, $1,550 for roundtrip airfare from the US to Dakar, Senegal.

Community Voice uses digital distribution of partner communities' recordings in order to minimize infrastructure while maximizing both audience reach and funding for communities' development work. However, here on Indiegogo, in addition to digital downloads, we're offering some unique perks including limited edition CDs, photographs and stories from the field, and other chances to get connected with our work.
Plus, every track that we include in our incentive packages, whether download or physical recording, will automatically generate $1 for the community that produced the song (for example, if you support us at the $10 level and receive three downloads, $3 goes directly to the communities from which you download your songs).
Expand your impact in the final days: For the remainder of the campaign, for every new contribution made, we will give one additional download on top of your existing incentive (you must select an incentive to be eligible for this). You will not only get an additional song, but you will be sending $1 more to a partner community. That means your new $10 contribution will now generate $4 for the communities which performed the music you choose.
 
Announcing new incentives: we just added our "Drummer" and "Globe-trotter" levels of giving. Want to feel a greater physical connection with the cultures in Senegal? These incentives may be for you.
Bonus music from Adam Klein: From now until the end of the campaign for any new contribution of $100 or more, singer/songwriter, Returned Peace Corps Volunteer, and Community Voice Board Member Adam Klein is offering up two of his most recently relased CDs:

Malian music album Dugu Wolo, recorded in Bamako, Mali and featuring traditional West African instrumentation by some of Mali's master musicians

The new Americana/folk album Sky Blue DeVille

Adam is offering these in addition to the other incentives you will also receive at this level. Thank you for your generosity, Adam!
The Impact
The main goal of this project will be recording music from partner communities to sell online in order to fund local development work. Stay tuned for updates to find out the communities in which we'll be working and what projects they have planned. 
Beyond realizing the mission of transforming music into funds for development, this campaign will also support Community Voice's work, allowing us to:


Streamline our recording process;


Experiment with different kinds of equipment to determine what works the best in the field;


And most importantly, to talk with members of our partner communities to find out how our work can better facilitate their development efforts.

Community Voice is pushing forward as an organization, trying to become more sustainable and effective at what we do. Your support will help us to prove that the concept of recording local music to fund local development really works. That proof of concept will allow us to help thousands of people in the years to come.

Other Ways You Can Help
Thank you all for supporting Community Voice International and our partner communities. We know that not everyone who supports our work will be able to contribute to this campaign; there are lots of other ways to help:


Tell your friends, family, neighbors, coworkers, pets, and complete strangers about our project and encourage them to check out our campaign on Indiegogo. The share tools above make it simple to share via social media or email.


Are you a whiz at web development? ...a PR guru? ...a master recording engineer? ...an ethnomusicology grad student? ...a philanthropic person with a few extra minutes? Volunteer for Community Voice! Contact me and let me know you're interested.
You're creative and have an amzing idea about how you contribute to our work. Please contact me and share your idea!
Like us on Facebook, follow us on Twitter, and visit our website to stay informed about new music releases and other Community Voice updates.

Thank you all for your support!

story:
We challenge everybody to support good music by supporting our debut album to be released. Expect anything from old school death metal, melodic death metal to black metal. Some of the old songs can be checked from the video medley on this page.
We'll hit the studio in May and release for the album is planned for late summer or early autumn.
We have released two demo CD's so far. A Familiar Room was released in 2011 and Apparition of Ending was released in 2012. Prints weren't that big, only 100 to 150 each.
Promoting everything by ourselves is tough work. Now we have support from Inverse Records, but we still need support for funding the studio, promotion and releasing the album. That's really important for us.With this support we'll have the opportunity to release this record as planned and in return everyone gets an album full of great metal of death.

Line-up:

Timo Hanhikangas - Guitar
Jonas Frilund - Bass
Timo Kontio - Guitar
Mathias Lillmåns - Vocals
Janne Manninen - Drums

More info at

http://www.facebook.com/MagentaHarvest

story:
Real quick, you can listen to our first LP here: http://thelongshotsska.bandcamp.com/

 

Some of you may already know us...

... but some of you may not.  We have been playing the Northwest Ska and Reggae scene for over five years now.  We have grown together as musicians and writers and we are very excited to get into the studio and record thirteen new songs with producer Brian Wallace.  This will be our third studio album. Our first an EP was recorded at Roadrunner Studios in Eugene, and mixed by our bass player, Tom Wade.  Our second album, an LP, was recorded at the University of Oregon School of Music by Peter Brewer and mixed once again by Tom.  Our plan for this third album, an LP, will be to record at Sprout City Studios in Eugene with Thaddeus Moore (owner/engineer) and Brian Wallace by our sides.  

What We Need 

Your contribution will help us fund the following expenses in recording our new album:

  • Cost to hire and lodging/airfare for Brian Wallace: $3000
  • Hiring a promoter and artist for the album: $750
  • Cost of renting Sprout City Studios with an engineer: $1300
  • Cost of pressing CD's: $1200

For a total of $6250.  We set a goal of $8000 in the case that we do not reach our goal or have unexpected expenses.

What You Get

Anyone who makes a contribution over $20 will have our new album, once finished, shipped anywhere.  

  • Contributions over $50 will receive: A signed copy of our new album, once finished, along with a copy of our second LP shipped to your door.
  • Contributions over $100: A signed copy of our new album, once finished, with a copy of our second LP and two T-shirts of your choosing (many sizes and colors, men's and women's) shipped to your door.
  • Contributions over $250: A signed copy of our new album, once finished, with a copy of our second LP and two T-shirts of your choosing, plus a private concert at a location of your choosing with The Longshots in Oregon or Washington (subject to availability of the band and will include at the very least our acoustic instrumentation of sax, cajon, vocals and guitar).

Bring back traditional and modern ska!

For those who know ska and reggae well, popular music hasn't seen much of it these days.  Help us help others discover (and re-discover) this wonderful form of music by checking out bands that have influenced us:

  • Westbound Train
  • The Slackers
  • Sublime
  • The Aggrolites
  • Jimmy Cliff
  • The Skatalites
  • Toots and the Maytals
  • Reel Big Fish
  • Two tone records
  • Chris Murray
  • Western Standard Time

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't make a donation, just give us a listen and let us know if you like it.  Friend us on facebook and keep up to date with our shows; we might just be coming to your town soon enough, and we'd love to sit down with you and talk anything, from music to love to life.  Thank you so much everybody!

https://www.facebook.com/thelongshotsska

http://thelongshotsska.bandcamp.com/

http://www.reverbnation.com/thelongshotsska

https://twitter.com/thelongshotsor

story:
EPHEBIA FESTIVAL 2013: ABBIAMO BISOGNO DI TE!

(The English version is at the end)

Ephebia Festival, l'evento musicale che da quindici anni porta il meglio della musica emergente italiana e internazionale nel centro della città di Terni, per tutti e gratuitamente.

 

L'Associazione Ephebia è gestita da volontari e ha sempre posto in primo piano la nostra città, Terni, e i suoi musicisti, permettendo a tutti loro di suonare durante i giorni del Festival, il cui palco è stato solcato da band come Afterhours, Linea 77, The Ark, LNRipley, Zen Circus, Bud Spencer Blues Explosion, Il Teatro Degli Orrori e molti altri.

I volontari, però, poco possono fare senza il sostegno delle istituzioni e del pubblico, ed è qui ed ora che abbiamo bisogno di te.

Non chiediamo molto, quello che basta per sostenere alcune spese e magari avere quel piccolo bonus per poter chiamare quell'artista che ti piace tanto.
Ovviamente, non sarebbe nel nostro spirito chiedere senza dare qualcosa in cambio!
Ecco quindi che, a seconda di quanto desideri donare, avrai in cambio un piccolo regalo a simbolo della nostra gratitudine, visto che se Ephebia 2013 si farà e sarà sensazionale...sarà anche grazie a te!

 

DI COSA ABBIAMO BISOGNO, COSA POSSIAMO DARTI

 

Noi di Ephebia abbiamo sempre organizzato il festival grazie ai fondi pubblici. Negli ultimi anni, tuttavia, i recenti tagli aila cultura hanno portato di conseguenza ad ingenti tagli nei fondi destinati al Festival. Per questo motivo quest'anno il tuo aiuto diventa fondamentale. 1500 € che ci permetteranno di organizzare un festival memorabile, nella suggestiva cornice dell'Anfiteatro romano a Terni.

Ciò che possiamo dare in cambio, oltre al nostro impegno nell'organizzare il miglior festival possibile, sono piccoli premi che significano molto: gadgets, spillette, memorabilia di edizioni passate, maglie.

Inoltre la lista dei perks sarà continuamente aggiornata man mano che le band daranno la loro disponibilità nel mettere a disposizione il loro merchandising e...perchè no, il loro tempo! 

 

L'IMPATTO

L'edizione passata ha visto partecipare migliaia di persone che hanno riempito l'anfiteatro e che insieme a noi hanno creato l'atmosfera magica che da 15 anni caratterizza l'Ephebia Festival. Quest'anno il tuo aiuto farà la differenza. Non lasciare che tutto ciò si perda per colpa delle spietate dinamiche dell'austerità. 

 

NON PUOI CONTRIBUIRE? 

Sono tempi difficili e non tutti possono contribuire economicamente. Ci sono tuttavia molti modi con cui puoi aiutarci a raggiungere il nostro obiettivo:

  • Fa in modo che le persone accanto a te conoscano la nostra campagna

  • Condividi questa campagna su Facebook, Twitter ed in qualunque altro modo tu conosca!

  • Parla di noi ai tuoi amici, fa conoscere il nostro festival a chi come te ha a cuore la nostra causa e ha voglia di musica live gratuita!

  • Metti "Mi piace" sulla nostra pagina facebook (Ephebia Festival: https://www.facebook.com/ephebiafestival?fref=ts ), oppure aggiungici agli amici (https://www.facebook.com/ephebia?fref=ts ). Scrivici in bacheca, mandaci un messaggio e facci vedere il tuo amore, ti saremo comunque infinitamente grati! 

 

STAVOLTA TU PUOI FARE LA DIFFERENZA.

 

 

 

 

EPHEBIA FESTIVAL 2013: WE NEED YOU!

Ephebia Festival, the musical event which, from 15 years, brings the best of the italian and international emergent music to the center of Terni, for everyone and absolutely free.

 

Ephebia Association is made entirely of volunteers and it has always put in the first place our city, Terni, and its musicians, making everyone of them play during the Festival's days, whose stage has seen bands like Afterhours, Porcupine Tree, Linea 77, The Ark, LNRipley, Zen Circus, Bud Spencer Blues Explosion, Il Teatro Degli Orrori and many others.

However, volunteers can't do much without some financial aid from the government or from our fans, and for this reason now we need you.

We don't ask for much, just what we need to sustain some expenses and maybe to have that little bonus which will allow us to book that artist whom you like so much. Obviously, though, it wouldn't be in our spirit to ask for something without giving something else in return!  For this reason, depending on how much you'll want to donate, you'll have a gift, something as a token of our gratitude towards you, because if we're doing Ephebia 2013 and it'll be sensational...it will be also because of you!

 

WHAT WE NEED, WHAT WE CAN GIVE YOU

 

We at Ephebia have always organized the festival with government funds. In the last years, however, the recent financial cuts to culture led to great cuts to the funds for our event. For this reason your help is now essential for our festival. 1500 € will allow us to create a memorable festival, in the beautiful location of Anfiteatro Fausto in Terni.

What we can give in exchange, apart from our biggest efforts to organize the best festival possible, are small prizes which mean a lot to us: gadgets, pins, memorabilia from past editions, t-shirts.

The perks list will be updated frequently every time the bands will give their willingness to share with us some of their merchandise...or, who knows, maybe also some of their time!

 

THE IMPACT

The past edition saw thousands of people filling the Anfiteatro to its limits. People who, together with the bands and us, created the magical atmosphere which has characterized our Festival in 15 years. This year your help is going to make the difference. Don't let all this get lost (Like tears in the rain) because of some harsh austerity policies.

 

WHAT IF YOU CAN'T CONTRIBUTE? 

We understand that these are hard times and not everybody can contribute economically. By the way, there are a lot of other ways in which you can help us reach our goal:

  • Let the people you know read this campaign!

  • Share this campaign on Facebook, Twitter and in any other way you know!

  • Talk about us to your friends, let people who want more free live music and agree with our cause, like you do, know about our festival!

  • “Like” our Facebook Page (Ephebia Festival: https://www.facebook.com/ephebiafestival?fref=ts ), or add us to your friends (https://www.facebook.com/ephebia?fref=ts ). write us on our wall, send us a message and show your love, we'll be immensely thankful! 

 

THIS TIME YOU CAN MAKE THE DIFFERENCE.

story:
HELLO!

My name is Meia, and I have been writing songs, playing guitar and singing for about 15 years now- but... I've never recorded a CD. I would like to have recorded at least ONE CD in my lifetime. I put a piece of my soul in each song I write. People tell me I am incredibly talented, and that it's a shame I have no CD's to sell or leave as my legacy. So I am running this campaign to remedy that situation.

Why a campaign?

Because performing music is what I do for a living. If you are not a musician, you may not realize, it doesn't pay much... and merchandise are expensive investments. I DO have bills to pay, which take priority and that is why I need to raise funds online. Also, I don't have the skill or equipment to do the home studio thing, and the quality of my recordings matter to me, as my fans will be paying for this product.

My website is www.rebelwithasixstring.com

I do all my accounting, booking, taxes, instrument maintenance...etc. I basically run my own business. I'm not trying to be rich or famous, I just want to continue to do what I love and not have to "live to work" at a dead end meaningless job I hate. 

What I Need 

I need about $1,000 to get started, but my kickstarter failed at 650, so I'm shooting for 700 this time, and if I make more that's fantastic!! If not, I will have a good startup amount. I have a studio in mind, and this gentleman is from England... he has a private analog studio just outside of town, the gas to get there and back is going to be expensive, and I need to pay him for his time of course. I also have a friend willing to help produce and provide live recordings for a very small flat fee!

I also need to pay for original artwork/photography for the CD, printing & duplication of the CD's, and packaging as well. I really want this to look professional, like something you would purchase at the store. I also want to make .mp3 files available for purchase, and the licensing for that will require some filing fees as well as attorney consultation fees.

If there is enough left over, I would like to purchase stickers! I already bought buttons with the help of some generous cash donations!

What You Get

A little bit of everything! Depending on your donation, I will give you a sticker (or one of each if I do multiples) as well as one of each button I currently have printed, a CD* and any other merchandise that happen to come into my hands through this funding or donation. *required donation of $10 for a free CD

The Impact

If every fan on my Facebook page were to donate about $10 to my campaign- I would have my goal and then some!!! So every donation counts- every dollar counts. If you love local music, and think that the music industry is in desprate need of revival and needs more originality in the songs available- you've come to the right place!

Other Ways You Can Help

SPREAD THE WORD! Share the links! Listen to and SUPPORT LOCAL MUSIC, as well as small time musicians like me!
story_txt:
HELLO!
My name is Meia, and I have been writing songs, playing guitar and singing for about 15 years now- but... I've never recorded a CD. I would like to have recorded at least ONE CD in my lifetime. I put a piece of my soul in each song I write. People tell me I am incredibly talented, and that it's a shame I have no CD's to sell or leave as my legacy. So I am running this campaign to remedy that situation.
Why a campaign?
Because performing music is what I do for a living. If you are not a musician, you may not realize, it doesn't pay much... and merchandise are expensive investments. I DO have bills to pay, which take priority and that is why I need to raise funds online. Also, I don't have the skill or equipment to do the home studio thing, and the quality of my recordings matter to me, as my fans will be paying for this product.
My website is www.rebelwithasixstring.com
I do all my accounting, booking, taxes, instrument maintenance...etc. I basically run my own business. I'm not trying to be rich or famous, I just want to continue to do what I love and not have to "live to work" at a dead end meaningless job I hate. 
What I Need 


I need about $1,000 to get started, but my kickstarter failed at 650, so I'm shooting for 700 this time, and if I make more that's fantastic!! If not, I will have a good startup amount. I have a studio in mind, and this gentleman is from England... he has a private analog studio just outside of town, the gas to get there and back is going to be expensive, and I need to pay him for his time of course. I also have a friend willing to help produce and provide live recordings for a very small flat fee!
I also need to pay for original artwork/photography for the CD, printing & duplication of the CD's, and packaging as well. I really want this to look professional, like something you would purchase at the store. I also want to make .mp3 files available for purchase, and the licensing for that will require some filing fees as well as attorney consultation fees.
If there is enough left over, I would like to purchase stickers! I already bought buttons with the help of some generous cash donations!
What You Get
A little bit of everything! Depending on your donation, I will give you a sticker (or one of each if I do multiples) as well as one of each button I currently have printed, a CD* and any other merchandise that happen to come into my hands through this funding or donation. *required donation of $10 for a free CD


The Impact
If every fan on my Facebook page were to donate about $10 to my campaign- I would have my goal and then some!!! So every donation counts- every dollar counts. If you love local music, and think that the music industry is in desprate need of revival and needs more originality in the songs available- you've come to the right place!


Other Ways You Can Help
SPREAD THE WORD! Share the links! Listen to and SUPPORT LOCAL MUSIC, as well as small time musicians like me!

story:
SOULNIC is an annual FREE, family and community oriented, outdoor music festival and picnic featuring DJs playing soulful dance music.  SOULNIC not only provides families with an alternative and fun way to spend time together outdoors, but it's also a platform to inspire the spirit of charitable giving in a way that benefits creativity in our youth.

LOCATION: Griffith Park - Los Angeles, CA

DATE: June 29, 2013

TIME: 10AM - 9PM

PRESENTED BY: EXTRA MILD SAUCE (see below)

CHARITABLE PARTNERS: On A Mission, Inc. (www.joinoam.org) and A Place Called Home (www.apch.org)

 

CLICK HERE for a detailed summary (PDF) on the history of the event and how to participate with us as a SPONSOR.

More information on the event itself can be found HERE:

http://extramildsauce.com/soulnic/

Extra Mild Sauce is an organization of visionaries who create quality music events nationwide.  Their collective professional experience spans over 15 years in music, film and event planning.  Since 2009, they have been committed to bringing community and families together through their free event SOULNIC. This year the producers are celebrating their 4th Annual SOULNIC on Saturday, June 29, from 9am to 10pm in Griffith Park at the Crystal Springs picnic area.   Events have been established in cities like Chicago (Chosen Few), New York (Soul Summit) and Atlanta (House in the Park). This year SOULNIC returns to Los Angeles on Saturday, June 29th, in the Crystal Springs area of the park.

Community participation in Los Angeles has grown from its first event in 2010 with over 300 friends and family to over 2,000 people in 2012.  SOULNIC is a free, fun filled day at the park, for families, in an environment that promotes love, peace, unity and community.  “I love being able to bring my mom, my aunties, kids to an event for us to be together for an entire day,” said one of the many families that attended the day’s festivities.

Proceeds from this year’s event from sponsorships and donations will benefit two non-profit organizations: On a Mission, a non-profit helping youth become responsible and productive citizens while acquiring important life skills needed to become successful adults. Their programs are designed to encourage kids to become active members in their communities for positive results.

The second group is called A Place Called Home, a non-profit youth center in South Central Los Angeles founded in 1993 providing educational programs, counseling, mentoring, music, dance, art classes, and fitness opportunities that encourage and empower youth to take ownership of the quality and direction of their lives.

Please help make a difference in the community by contributing to the success of this cultural event.

And thank you for your support.

 ___________________

"From day one, SOULNIC has been about love, family, unity and community. My team and I have focused on providing an event that is free, family and community oriented and open to the general public. We also wanted to partner with children's charities, as our beneficiaries, in an effort to assist them with raising awareness and funds.

In the past, my team and I have covered all of the costs associated with the production of SOULNIC (permit, stage, sound and etc) and this number has increased each year. Last year's explosion in attendance (500-600 attendees in 2011 to well over 2000 in 2012) led Griffith Park to require we provide additional services in order for there to be a SOULNIC 2013. Within the last month, we were able to secure their most important request of offsite parking. We received the green light and SOULNIC 2013 was approved.

While the event has been approved and is a 'go', the additional services (offsite parking, shuttles, security, porta potties and etc) have raised the production budget exponentially (from just under $10K in the past to $47K) and my team and I cannot cover it ourselves. What started as a simple party in the park, that we didn't mind funding, has turned into a huge event that we cannot fund alone. We've laid the groundwork for the last 3 years and have taken SOULNIC as far as we can, by ourselves, in year number 4.

If the 4th Annual SOULNIC Music Festival is going to happen, it will only happen if the people mobilize behind it and make it happen. Your support is greatly needed and is a must. We've partnered with On A Mission, a children's charity and 501(c)(3), who has volunteered to be our Fiscal Sponsor. Meaning, ALL donations are accepted and managed by On A Mission and are TAX DEDUCTIBLE.

I'm asking if you will help us make SOULNIC 2013 happen by making a tax deductible donation, of at least $10, along with spreading the word to your network of family, friends and colleagues and asking them to make a small donation as well.

Moving forward, we will be working our hardest to procure corporate sponsorship so SOULNIC 2014 can go back to being what SOULNIC was set out to be from the beginning, a fun day in the sun for families that's free and open to all.

"Let's keep SOULNIC alive, donate today AND SPREAD THE WORD."

-Chevez Frazier
Co-Founder
EXTRA MILD SAUCE

story:
THUG it up!

The long awaited album 'Benevolence' has finally been released! I hope everyone has gotten a chance to listen to it as a whole. This new album is a huge landmark for my musicianship and composition skills. It's taken me what seems like forever to finish it and I hope you're as happy with the outcome as I am! As a fellow lover of music, I want people to enjoy my music as easily and efficiently as possible, so I will have my music available for free download at thug.bandcamp.com. With this being the case, the funds for producing new merchandise come from selling past merchandise. Unfortunately, my imagination and ambitions got the best of me this time around and I plan on producing with much higher quality clothes and many more options to choose from. This is where you come in! With your help, THUG can start looking like a professional project with sleek CD's and a full line of awesome merchandise.

What do you get?

Basically, you're getting a pre-sale for the perk you choose! $2,200 is a lot of money for a solo musician with bigger dreams than most people would find achievable, but I believe with my determination and your help, we can do it! Plus, it's a win-win situation no matter how you look at it!

  • Physical copies of 'Benevolence'
  • Shirts
  • Hoodies
  • Stickers (coming soon)
  • Sunglasses (coming sooner!)

Once I receive the funds, I can start ordering everything right away to ensure your product/perk is delivered to you as soon as possible! The funds will be going straight to a special bank account that will ONLY be used for exactly what's stated: new THUG merch! 

Upper Left Design T-Shirt:

Hoodie:

Owl T-Shirt:

NOTE: After contributing for a shirt or hoodie, you will recieve a message shortly at the end of the campaign (Jan 4th) asking what size you need. You should receive your item by the end of January.


Who cares?

THUG is my project that I've brought up from the ground by myself with some help from friends along the way (of whom I'm extremely thankful for). I write, record, and produce the music myself as well as promote and play shows by myself. The past album's CD's were all printed and burned in my bedroom. Even all of THUG's shirts are hand screen-printed by my dad and I! It really doesn't get any more DIY than this. Although it's nice to be able to take pride in everything that's made by your own hands and hard work, it's much better to see an amazing finished project in front of you all because of your dedicated fans. With your help, I can get sleek new CD's and new merch professionally manufactured. So in the end, not only will THUG become a more competent looking project, but you'll care because you'll be wearing higher quality clothing and will have helped someone achieve their dream.

Other Ways You Can Help

Help by telling everyone you know and putting this page up all over your facebook, twitter, tumblr, and any other social networking website! (myspace?)

Download Benevolence for free at the following bandcamp link!

-http://thug.bandcamp.com/

Go buy some of the previously printed merch, which includes two T-shirts, a tank top, and THUG's first CD! The funds received from the previous batch of merch will go directly to supporting this fundraiser as well.

-https://www.thugmerch.bigcartel.com

Like THUG on facebook! The more people like THUG, the more publicity it will receive and the more people will see the goal you're helping to support!

-https://www.facebook.com/THUGmusicFL

Also, be sure to check out some of our cool videoes on youtube and to follow THUG on twitter!

-https://twitter.com/THUGband

-https://www.youtube.com/user/thatgoodgoodTHUGjam


Thank you so much for the support, whether it be through funding this campaign, telling your friends, or simply jamming to THUG every day! Through this, you are helping me achieve my goal and life long dream of becoming a successful musician. I'm extremely grateful for any help, no matter how insignificant you may think it is.

-Nick
